person.note: Former president of the Bibliographical Society of the University of Virginia; author of Books in My Life; contributor to Studies in Bibliography for forty-six consecutive volumes; recipient of the Bibliographical Society (England) Gold Medal, 2015.
Curator emeritus at the Morgan Library & Museum.

Curator of special collections, Carnegie Mellon University Libraries; editor of The Four Shakespeare Folios, 1623–2023: Copy, Print, Paper, Type; publications in The Library, Papers of the Bibliographical Society of America, Eighteenth-Century Studies, and others.

MA, University of Virginia; former director, UVA Alderman Library Card Catalog Preservation Project; fellowships from the Bibliographical Society of UVA, Lewis Walpole Library, and Rare Book School; William Reese Fellow (2020); Director of Implementation, Citeline.
Postdoctoral researcher, Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin; work in Book History, New Literary History, American Literature, and ALH.
Associate Professor of Spanish and Digital Humanities, University of Georgia; author of Borges and the Literary Marketplace (2021); co-editor of The Oxford Handbook of Jorge Luis Borges (2024).

Emeritus Professor of Textual Criticism, University of Keele; author of Pope, Print, and Meaning (2001); saw David Foxon’s Pope and the Early Eighteenth-Century Book Trade (1991) and David Fleeman’s A Bibliography of the Works of Samuel Johnson (2000) through the press.

Formerly taught English, University of Alberta; author of Sixteenth-Century English Dictionaries (vol. 1 of Dictionaries in the English-Speaking World, 1500–1800, 2022); contributor to The Cambridge Handbook of the Dictionary (2024).

Fellow of the Society of Antiquaries; Honorary Research Fellow, University of Liverpool; Chairman, Dr Johnson’s House Trust; recent books include The Selected Letters of Horace Walpole (2017) and Lefty Lewis and the Waldegraves (2022).
Professor, English Department, Doshisha University, Kyoto; specialist in British Romantic literature and Charles Dibdin; founding director, Retrospect Opera.

Miranker Family Director of Collections, Exhibitions & Scholarly Initiatives, Rare Book School (UVA); Brontë scholar; co-author of Building the Book from the Ancient World to the Present Day (2022) and co-editor of Teaching Text Technologies and Critical Bibliography among the Disciplines (forthcoming 2025).
Professor of Music Emeritus, Colgate University; Honorary Fellow, Society of Antiquaries, London; author/translator of c. 40 books on Western esotericism and speculative music.

E. E. Sparks Professor of English Emeritus, Pennsylvania State University; general editor, The Cambridge Edition of the Works of F. Scott Fitzgerald; editor of The Cambridge Centennial Edition of The Great Gatsby (2025).
